title.narrative: Protection Monitoring and Increased Access to Information for Conflict Affected People in East and West Mosul

description.narrative: Oxfam aims to meet the critical protection needs of conflict affected people in East and West Mosul by providing an integrated protection package that addresses the need for ongoing protection monitoring of recently displaced people and returnees, and provides affected populations with information and a means to access services for life-saving protection interventions and family reunification. This project will provide information on access to services, protection monitoring at initial contact points for immediately displaced people, cash for protection to reduce, eliminate or prevent protection risks, and promote local, national and international level advocacy around immediate protection violations to prevent or eliminate these patterns of identified issues. Through on-going protection assessments in newly retaken and recent returnee locations in Mosul city and surrounding areas Oxfam will be able to identify the most vulnerable communities and at risk conflict affected people in order to inform our own protection response, Oxfam’s WASH and EFSVL response, and the cluster and authorities responses to the needs of conflict affected people in Mosul. Oxfam’s protection presence will allow up to create and update service mapping and referral information dissemination as well as provide the protection team the platform to distribute ongoing information dissemination around protection information packages where we’ve identified concerns through assessments conducted from August 2016 to April 2017 and ongoing in this project. Protection issues identified so far include child soldier recruitment, violations of IHL, early child marriage, lack of access or restriction to basic needs and services as well as livelihoods opportunities when returning. There are also concerns regarding abductions, internment, killings, and detainment of adolescent and adult men, leaving families vulnerable and at risk and not knowing where male members of the family are. Our ongoing work in the Mosul response and engagement with communities has found civil Identification/legal documentation has been destroyed, lost, taken, or unable to have been created due to the protracted conflict and sudden displacement which in result has restricted families from accessing available services or claiming their rights. Oxfam will address these needs through connected Protection activities that aims to prevent, reduce and eliminate protection issues in the Mosul response with the following components: - On going protection and needs assessments such as PRAs etc. - Protection Monitoring at Mustering/Initial Contact Points - Service mapping and referral information - Information dissemination - Cash for protection - Advocacy
